item.title: Closed Subgroup Theorem
item.description: Motivation & Statement

item.title: Partition of Unity
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Let $X$ be a topological space. One might want to construct a continuous function $f:X\to\R$ satisfying certain properties, but this can be very hard. Instead, one constructs a family $f_\alpha:U_\alpha\to\R$ of continuous functions on a (suitably ‘simple’) open cover $\l\{U_\alpha\r\}$ of $X$, and hope that they agree on intersections; that is, hope that $f_\alpha(U_\alpha\cap U_\beta)=f_\beta(U_\alpha\cap U_\beta)$ for all $\alpha,\beta$. Then, since continuous maps form a sheaf, one can glue them together to obtain the desired (global) continuous function $f:X\to\R$.

item.title: Finite Graph
item.description:
Let $G$ be a (simple) graph. The condition that $V(G)$ be finite allows us to apply methods from finite combinatorics to analyze $G$. We give some graph-theoretic frameworks for which such combinatorics applies to. Ultimately, these arguments boil down to applying the Pigeonhole Principle, or using the fact that $\N$ is well-ordered.


  However, certain results from finite graph theory have more elegant proofs if we are willing to use techniques involving infinite graphs, and in some cases, those are the only known proofs. The prototypical example of this bridge is Ramsey’s Theorem.

item.title: Degree (Graph Theory)
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Let $G$ be a (simple) graph. Although very crude, good control over the degree of a vertex in $G$ can form the basis of some interesting combinatorial results when $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, this notion can instead be used as a measure of the local complexity of $G$.

item.title: Lie Group
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Definition. A Lie group is a smooth manifold $G$ equipped with a group structure $(G,\mu,\iota)$ such that the multiplication $\mu$ and the inversion $\iota$ are smooth maps.

Lie Algebras

The Exponential Map

General Techniques

Lie Group Actions

Representation Theory

item.title: Tangent Space of Manifolds
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

In elementary calculus on $\R^2$, one uses the techniques of derivatives, and hence tangent lines at a point, to study the local behaviour of curves. This philosophy of probing the local structure of the space via derivatives is the raison d’être of smooth manifolds, and they provide a suitable structure to define a well-behaved notion of tangent spaces.

item.title: Smooth Manifold
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

The theory of smooth manifolds gives an appropriate setting to do calculus in higher dimensions and curved spaces. Classically, this is done within $\R^n$, but we would like to work in a more abstract setting without embeddings into $\R^n$. This begs the following question:

How can we faithfully transport the fundamental properties of $\R$ that makes calculus possible to more abstract spaces?

Indeed, the main property of $\R$ is that it is the unique$^\dagger$ complete ordered field, which calculus is based on, so any such abstract notion must make contact with $\R$. We will consider (topological) manifolds as the abstract spaces, which has charts that make contact with $\R$, so it remains to faithfully represent the smooth structure of $\R$.

item.title: Connected Space
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Definition. A topological space $X$ is said to be connected if $\em,X$ are the only clopen sets in $X$.
Theorem. If $f:X\to Y$ is a continuous map and $X$ is connected, then so is $f(X)$.
Proof. Click to expand... We prove the contrapositive, so write $f(X)=V_1\sqcup V_2$ for some non-empty disjoint open sets $V_i\subseteq f(X)$. Then $U_i\coloneqq f^{-1}(V_i)$ are non-empty disjoint open sets of $X$ with $X=U_1\sqcup U_2$, as desired.$\blacksquare$

Path-connectedness

Let $x,y\in X$. A path from $x$ to $y$ is a continuous map $\gamma:[0,1]\to\R$ such that $\gamma(0)=x$ and $\gamma(1)=y$. We usually express this by writing $\gamma:x\pathto y$. As expected the definition for path-connectedness is as follows.

item.title: Compact Space
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Definition. A topological space $X$ is compact if every open cover of $X$ admits a finite subcover, i.e., if $U_\alpha\subseteq X$ is a collection of open subsets such that $X=\bigcup_\alpha U_\alpha$, then there is some $n\in\N$ and $\alpha_1,\dots,\alpha_n$ such that $X=\bigcup_{i\leq n}U_{\alpha_i}$.
Theorem. If $f:X\to Y$ is a continuous map and $X$ is compact, then so is $f(X)$.
Proof. Click to expand... Let $\l\{V_\alpha\r\}$ be an cover of $f(X)$ by open subsets of $Y$. Then each $f^{-1}(V_\alpha)$ is open in $X$ and $\l\{f^{-1}(V_\alpha)\r\}$ is an open cover of $X$, so it cuts down to a finite subcover $X=\bigcup_{i\leq n}f^{-1}(V_{\alpha_i})$. Observe that $f(X)\subseteq\bigcup_{i\leq n}V_{\alpha_i}$, so $f(X)$ is compact as desired.$\blacksquare$

item.title: Structure Theorem for Finitely-generated Modules over PIDs
item.description: Motivation & Statement

item.title: Smith Normal Form
item.description:
Motivation & Statement

Theorem (Smith Normal Form). Let $R$ be a PID.

Algorithms for the Smith Normal Form

In addition to being a PID, further restrictions on $R$ allow us to (algorithmically!) compute the Smith Normal Form for any matrix $A\in\mc{M}_{m\times n}(R)$. We present two algorithms below, one for when $R$ is a Euclidean domain, and then other when $R$ is a field (in which case the algorithm is commonly called the Gaussian algorithm). Both algorithms require the notion of an elementary matrix.

item.title: Principal Ideal Domain
item.description: Motivation & Definition

item.title: Field
item.description: Motivation & Definition

item.title: Basis (Module Theory)
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Given an $R$-module $M$ over a commutative ring $R$, it is useful to know whether there is a ‘simple’ generating set of $M$. Properties of $M$ will then be entirely determined by $S$, so classifying such subsets will lead to a classification of modules. Clearly $M$ generates itself, but this generation is clearly redundant (if $M\neq\l\{0\r\}$), so we need to cut those generating sets down to remove redundancies.

item.title: Vector Space
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

The theory of vector spaces stems from classical dynamics (say, in the plane $\R^2$), where points $x\in\R^2$ move along paths with certain velocities, which we call vectors. At a fixed time, the space of vectors can be visualized as arrow whose directions indicate in the possible headings of $x$ and whose lengths indicate the possible speeds of $x$. We can add these vectors and scale them by any $r\in\R$, and we can (non-uniquely) identify two special basis vectors in which every other velocity is a linear combination of the two.

item.title: Prime and Maximal Ideals
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Fix a commutative ring $R$. Any ideal $\mf{a} subgrpeq R$ induces a quotient ring $R/\mf{a}$ that makes $\pi:R\onto R/\mf{a}$ a ring homomorphism. If $\mf{a} eq R$, then $R/\mf{a}$ might have a simpler structure than $\mf{a}$, say, $R/\mf{a}$ might be an integral domain or a field.

Definition. A non-trivial ideal $\mf{a} subgrp R$ is said to be prime (resp. maximal) if $R/\mf{a}$ is an integral domain (resp. a field).

Remark. Note that $\mf{p}$ is prime iff $rs\in\mf{p}$ implies either $r\in\mf{p}$ or $s\in\mf{p}$, which is reminiscent to prime numbers in $\Z$. Moreover, $\mf{m}$ is maximal iff it is $\subseteq$-maximal in the lattice of non-trivial ideals of $R$. The latter follows from the Lattice Isomorphism Theorem: any ideal $ ar{\mf{a}} subgrpeq R/\mf{m}$ corresponds to some (unique) ideal $\mf{a} subgrpeq R$ containing $\mf{m}$, so a non-trivial ideal $ ar{\mf{a}} subgrp R/\mf{m}$ vanishes iff $\mf{m}$ is $\subseteq$-maximal, and the former occurs$^\dagger$ iff $R/\mf{m}$ is a field.

item.title: Kernel (Ring Theory)
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Definition. The kernel of a ring homomorphism $f:R\to S$ is the ideal $\ker f\coloneqq f^{-1}(0_S)$ of $R$.

TODO (somehow this relates to regular categories and kernel pairs).

item.title: Group of Units
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Elements in a ring may not be invertible; that is, there may exist $r\in R$ such that $rs\neq1$ or $sr\neq1$ for all $s\in R$ (see here for details). Thus, it is useful to group together the elements that are invertible, which in fact forms a group under multiplication.

Definition. The group of units of a ring $R$ is the set $R^\times\coloneqq\l\{u\in R\st(\ex r\in R)ur=1=ru\r\}$ equipped with multiplication.
Proof ($R^\times$ is a group). Click to expand... If $u,u’\in R^\times$, then $u’r’=ur=1=ru=r’u’$ for some $r,r’\in R$. Then we have $$\begin{equation} (uu’)(r’r)=u(u’r’)r=ur=1=r’u’=r’(ru)u’=(r’r)(uu’), \end{equation}$$ so $R^\times$ is closed under multiplication. The unit $1\in R$ is the identity since $1\cdot1=1$, and $\cdot$ is clearly associative.$\blacksquare$

Remark. Note that if $R=\End G$ for some abelian group $G$, then $R^\times=\Aut G$.

item.title: Second Countable Space
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

One way to measure the ‘complexity’ of a topological space is to limit the cardinality of bases thereof, and since the most important cardinal is probably $\aleph_0$, we make the following

Definition. A topological space $X$ is second countable if it admits a countable basis.

In the setting of a metrizable space, this limitation is equivalent$^\dagger$ to some others (like, separability, being Lindelöf, and the CCC). In general, however, second countability is stronger than the rest.

item.title: Separable Space
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

A standard technique from analysis is when establishing a property for some topological space $X$, one first proves it for a dense subset $C\subseteq X$. It is thus useful to prove the existence of ‘nice’ dense sets. The following is singles out a very crude such class of spaces.

Definition. A topological space $X$ is said to be separable if it admits a countably dense subset $Q\subseteq X$.

This provides a limitation on the ‘complexity’ of $X$, and, in the setting of a metrizable space $X$, this limitation is equivalent$^\dagger$ to some others (like second countability, being Lindelöf, and the CCC). Thus, we usually focus on the metrizable case, and more often than not, on Polish spaces (those which are completely metrizable).

item.title: Metrizable Space
item.description: Motivation & Definition

item.title: Hausdorff Space
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Let $X$ be a topological space. From the point of view of the topology on $X$, two points are distinguishable iff they can be ‘separated’ by open sets. For instance, if $X$ is discrete, then point are separated, while if $X$ has the trivial topology, then no points are separated. There are different degrees of separation; the most common and useful one is as follows.

item.title: Manifold
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Definition.

Let $n\in\N$. An $n$-dimensional manifold is a second countable Hausdorff space $M$ that is ‘locally-Euclidean’, in the sense every point $p\in M$ admits a neighborhood $U\ni p$ and a map $\phi:U\to\R^n$ that is a homeomorphism onto its image.


  We refer to the pair $(U,\phi)$ as a coordinate chart around $p$; if $\phi(p)=0$, then we say that $(U,\phi)$ is centered at $p$.

item.title: Bases for Topologies
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Let $X$ be a set. To specify a topology on $X$, one needs to give a complete description of its open sets. In practice, however, specifying a certain subcollection $\mc{B}\subseteq\pow(X)$ will suffice, In which case we say that the topology is generated by $\mc{B}$. Two questions arise:

  1. If $\mc{T}$ is a given topology on $X$, what subcollections $\mc{B}\subseteq\mc{T}$ generate $\mc{T}$?
  2. What kinds of collections $\mc{B}\subseteq\pow(X)$ can specify some topology $\mc{T}$ on $X$?

Generation of a Fixed Topology

Let $\mc{T}$ be a fixed topology on $X$.

item.title: Convergence
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

The idea of convergence of elements $x_\alpha$ in $X$ is to find a single element $x\in X$ that is ‘close’ to as many elements $x_\alpha$ as possible. This heuristic can be formalized in many ways; here, we focus on interpreting ‘closeness’ in the topological sense.


  Throughout, let $X$ be a topological space. For each $x\in X$, let $\mc{N}_x$ denote the set of all not necessarily open neighborhoods of $x$, i.e., sets $A\subseteq X$ containing $x$ such that $x\in U\subseteq A$ for some open set $U$. A neighborhood base of $x$ is a subset $\mc{B}_x\subseteq\mc{N}_x$ such that every $U\in\mc{N}_x$ contains some $B\in\mc{B}_x$.

item.title: Filter
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Definition.

Let $P$ be a poset. A filter on $P$ is a subset $\em\neq F\subseteq P$ such that

  1. (Upward-closure). If $p\in F$ and $q\geq p$, then $q\in F$.
  2. (Downward-directed). If $p_1,p_2\in F$, then there exists $q\in F$ with $q\leq p_1,p_2$.

item.title: Equivalence Relation
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Oftentimes, we wish to regard two objects as ‘being the same’ (for instance, two sets are ‘the same’ if they have the same cardinality), despite them not being equal. The concept of an equivalence relation can be thought of as a generalization of equality.

Definition.

Let $X$ be a set. An equivalence relation on $X$ is a (binary) relation $E\subseteq X^2$ subject to the following conditions.

item.title: Ring
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

The concept of a ring naturally arises when studying the endomorphism group of an abelian group $G$. Indeed, $\End G$ is itself abelian, but more importantly, it has an extra operation of composition. These operations are compatible in the sense below.

Definition. A ring is a tuple $(R,+,\cdot,0,1)$ consisting of a monoid $(R,\cdot,1)$ and an abelian group $(R,+,0)$, where the two structures are compatible in the following way: For all $r,s,t\in R$, we have the distributive laws $$\begin{equation} (r+s)\cdot t=r\cdot t+s\cdot t\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \mathit{and}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ t\cdot(r+s)=t\cdot r+t\cdot s. \end{equation}$$

Remark. Note that although many rings arise as $\End(G)$ for some abelian group $G$, they do not exhaust all rings; a counterexample is the ring $\Z/2\Z\times\Z/2\Z$, or the family of rings $\F_{p^2}$ for $p$ prime (the latter are finite fields). See, however, Cayley’s Theorem for rings, which states that every ring $R$ is a subring of $\End(R)$, where $R$ is its underlying abelian group.

item.title: Limits & Colimits
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Fix a category $C$.

Definition.

Let $C,J$ be categories and fix a functor $F\in C^J$. A colimit of $F$ is a universal arrow $(r,u)$ from $F$ to the diagonal functor $\Delta:C\to C^J$.

Similarly, a limit of $F$ is a universal arrow $(t,v)$ from $\Delta$ to $F$.

Representable Functors

Universal Elements

Examples

(Co)products

(Co)equalizers

Fibered (Co)products

Directed (Co)limits

item.title: The Yoneda Lemma
item.description:
The Yoneda Embedding $\yo$

Statement & Proof

Fix a locally-small category $C$. $\yo:C\to\catset$

Theorem (Yoneda). Let $C$ be a locally-small category. For every functor $F:C\to\catset$ and every object $c\in C$, we have a bijection $$\begin{equation} y\coloneqq y_{F,c}:\Hom(C(c,\slot),F)\to Fc\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \mathit{sending}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \big(\eta:C(c,\slot)\to F\big)\mapsto\eta_c1_c, \end{equation}$$ which is moreover natural in both $F$ and $c$.
Proof (Bijection). Click to expand...

Define a function $t\coloneqq t_{F,c}:Fc\to\Hom(C(C,\slot),F)$ by sending an element $a\in Fc$ to the natural transformation $t(a):C(c,\slot)\to F$ via $$\begin{equation} t(a)_d:C(c,d)\to Fd\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \textrm{mapping}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ (f:c\rightarrow d)\mapsto Ff(a)\in Fd \end{equation}$$ for each $d\in C$. That $a=y(t(a))$ is immediate since $t(a)_c(1_c)=F(1_c)a=1_ca=a$.

item.title: Universal Constructions
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Universal Arrows

Definition.

Let $F:D\to C$ be a functor and fix $c\in C$. A universal arrow from $c$ to $F$ is an initial object in $(c\downto F)$. That is, it is a pair $(r,u)$, with $r\in D$ and $u:c\to Fr$, inducing for each $d\in D$ a bijection $$\begin{equation} \phi_d:D(r,d)\to C(c,Fd):f’\mapsto Ff’\circ u. \end{equation}$$ This can be visualized as in the following diagram.

Remark. The bijection $\phi_d$ is natural in $d$, for if $g’:d\to d’$, then $$\begin{equation} F(g’\circ f’)\circ u=Fg’\circ(Ff’\circ u) \end{equation}$$ for every morphism $f’:r\to d$, making its naturality square commute. Conversely, by the Yoneda Lemma, every natural isomorphism $\phi:D(r,\slot)\to C(c,F\slot)$ arises in this way via a unique universal arrow $u:c\to Fr$ from $c$ to $F$.

item.title: Natural Transformation
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Definition.

Let $F,G:C\to D$ be covariant functors between categories $C$ and $D$. A natural transformation $\eta:F\to G$ is a function assigning to each $c\in C$ a morphism $\eta_c:Fc\to Gc$ of $D$ such that for every $f\in C(c,c’)$, the diagram

commutes.

item.title: Category
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

The starting point of the theory of categories is the observation that many properties of mathematical objects can be more succinctly expressed as diagrams of arrows $-$ as opposed to an equation $-$ and that many objects can be constructed via a ‘universal property’ of such a diagram; heuristically then, these objects are characterized as the ‘most efficient solution to a certain optimization problem’.


   To formalize this, we need a general framework for composing arrows, so we make the following

item.title: Metric Space
item.description:
Motivation & Definition

Let $X$ be a set. We would like to formalize a notion of ‘distance’ between points $x,x’\in X$, and we do so by abstracting away some basic properties of the Euclidean distance in $\R^n$, and most notably preserving the Triangle Inequality.

Definition.

Let $X$ be a set. A metric on $X$ is a function $d:X\times X\to\R_{\geq0}$ such that

  1. (Positive-definiteness). For all $x,y\in X$, we have $d(x,y)=0$ iff $x=y$.
  2. (Symmetry.) For all $x,y\in X$, we have $d(x,y)=d(y,x)$.
  3. ($\Delta$-inequality). For all $x,y,z\in X$, we have $d(x,z)\leq d(x,y)+d(y,z)$.

If $d$ is a metric on $X$, we call the pair $\tpl{X,d}$ a metric space.
